channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Federal judge pauses Thursday deadline for Trump administration’s buyout program as labor groups sue to block it
item.description: A federal judge in Massachusetts temporarily paused the Trump administration’s buyout program’s deadline, which had been set for 11:59 p.m. Thursday, and set a new hearing for Monday.

item.title: Happening now: Post reporters answer your questions about buyouts and layoffs under Trump
item.description: Washington Post personal finance columnist Michelle Singletary and reporters Lisa Rein and Emily Davies are helping you understand the future of the federal workforce.

item.title: Elon Musk’s DOGE team is feeding sensitive federal data into AI via Microsoft's cloud to target spending cuts
item.description:
Musk’s representatives from the Department of Government Efficiency have fed data from across the Education Department — including personally identifiable information for people who manage grants and sensitive internal financial data — into artificial intelligence software to probe the agency’s programs and spending, according to two people with knowledge of the actions.
This use of AI, which has not previously been reported, shows how Musk’s group, which includes former employees from his tech empire, is tapping the favorite tool of Silicon Valley as part of its mission to drastically slash the size and functions of the federal government.

item.title: Trump administration sues Illinois and Chicago, accusing them of blocking immigration enforcement efforts
item.description: The lawsuit appears to be the first the Justice Department has filed after vowing to investigate state and local officials who impede President Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown. It seeks a court order to bar protections for undocumented immigrants that exist at the state and local level.

item.title: As Washington reels, Trump voters like what they see
item.description: Most who spoke to The Washington Post in Pennsylvania were in favor of President Donald Trump’s efforts to scale back the federal workforce, stand by his controversial Cabinet nominees and slash foreign aid.

item.title: Trump’s tariff whiplash: Six writers try to make sense of the twists and turns
item.description: On Feb. 1, President Donald Trump announced tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China. By Feb. 3, the tariffs threatened on Mexico and Canada were deferred for a month, while those on China stayed in place.

item.title: An ‘infinite sea’ of these animals in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Elon Musk’s DOGE agents have accessed sensitive personnel data at the Office of Personnel Management, alarming security officials
item.description: The highly restricted data includes personally identifiable information — including addresses, demographic profiles, salary details and disciplinary histories — for millions of federal employees.

item.title: Federal workers. Trump and Gaza. Transgender athletes. Bird flu. Tech layoffs. Store closures. Egg heist. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Countries are preparing for the worst after Trump's comments on Gaza, David Ignatius reports
item.description: To a region still recovering from the trauma of war, Trump’s proposed takeover of Gaza was incendiary.

item.title: Our personal finance columnist reviewed the ‘deferred resignation’ contract with a law professor. Her verdict: Don’t sign.
item.description: Our personal finance columnist reviewed the ‘deferred resignation’ contract with a law professor. Her verdict: Don’t sign.

item.title: Trump signs executive order that aims to ban trans student-athletes from competing on girls’ and women’s teams
item.description: The new order threatens to deny federal funds for schools that allow transgender athletes to compete in K-12 and college sports. It’s the latest salvo in President Donald Trump’s attack on transgender rights, another that will ricochet through schools across the country, as the president delivers on another contentious culture war promise.

item.title: Trump will not send funds to Gaza and hasn’t committed to sending troops, White House says, after his proposal to displace Gazans
item.description: White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters Wednesday that the United States “is not going to pay for the rebuilding of Gaza.” She also said President Donald Trump “has not committed” to putting boots on the ground there.

item.title: China considers pulling the plug on TikTok in the U.S. as it waits for a ‘grand deal’ on trade with Trump
item.description:
TikTok’s Chinese owner appears to be slow-rolling negotiations for a sale while waiting for a green light from the Chinese government, even as corporate allies of President Donald Trump race to broker a deal to sell the app to an American bidder, according to three people familiar with the talks, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss private business transactions.
But Beijing is increasingly likely to take a hard-line approach, letting TikTok’s U.S. operations die rather than approving a sale as it holds out for a “grand deal” with the Trump administration.

item.title: Federal judge indefinitely blocks Trump’s order to end birthright citizenship
item.description: Maryland U.S. District Judge Deborah L. Boardman issued the preliminary injunction on Wednesday in response to a lawsuit brought by civil rights groups. The injunction applies nationally and will remain in place as the case is adjudicated. The Trump administration is expected to appeal.

item.title: NWSL must create $5 million fund to compensate women’s soccer players abused by coaches and officials, new settlement states
item.description: The deal involves the attorneys general from Washington, D.C., Illinois and New York, and the NWSL Players Association. It was reached more than three years after allegations of harassment, emotional abuse and sexual misconduct sparked a crisis that rocked the league and sport, led to investigations and prompted a series of changes by the league.

item.title: An ‘everlasting’ musical instrument in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: USPS resumes accepting packages from China and Hong Kong hours after blocking them in effort to comply with Trump’s tariffs
item.description: Rather than refusing packages from China and Hong Kong entirely, the U.S. Postal Service says it will work with Customs and Border Protection on a way to collect new tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump.

item.title: Trump’s Gaza proposal. Elon Musk. Tariff impacts. Sweden shooting. Abortion pills. Winter storms. Expensive violin. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Most USAID workers to be put on leave as all overseas staff are recalled, Trump administration says
item.description: The move is the latest action in a jarring broadside against America’s foreign aid architecture that has followed President Donald Trump’s return to the White House. In the weeks since his inauguration, the new administration has announced a broad freeze on foreign aid programs — unleashing upheaval across the aid sector and financial crises for groups reliant on USAID funding — and fired, furloughed or put on leave the bulk of AID employees.

item.title: USPS suspends package service from China as Trump’s tariffs kick in
item.description: The U.S. Postal Service’s decision may block, at least temporarily, parcels from retailers including Shein and Temu from entering the United States.

item.title: Trump says U.S. would ‘take over’ Gaza Strip, says Palestinians should leave in news conference with Netanyahu
item.description: In a news conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Trump suggested Gazans should leave the war-torn area and that the U.S. would step in and “develop it,” possibly on a long-term basis and with U.S. military involvement.

item.title: Authorities say they’ve recovered the remains of all 67 people killed in last week’s midair crash. Here are many of their stories.
item.description: Among those killed were young figure skaters, soldiers, attorneys and a group that had been on a hunting trip, according to their families and friends.

item.title: New year, new pregnancy: This pronatalist couple wants to make America procreate again
item.description: Simone and Malcolm Collins, along with their soon-to-be five children, are avatars for a new pronatalist movement. With Trump 2.0, they’re more optimistic than ever.

item.title: Trump proposes permanent displacement of Gazans as he welcomes Netanyahu to White House
item.description: President Donald Trump framed the vision as a practical and humane response to the physical destruction of Gaza after 16 months of intense bombardment from Israel. His comments threatened to inflame the Arab world as Trump prepared to welcome Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to the White House on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Google drops its pledge not to develop AI for weapons, surveillance or in ways ‘likely to cause overall harm’
item.description: Executives said in a blog post that companies should create AI that “supports national security.”

item.title: Freezing rain could produce icy glaze in D.C. area Wednesday night into early Thursday morning
item.description: Untreated roads and walkways could become slick, causing school delays and closings. The National Weather Service has issued winter weather advisories for the region.

item.title: Tulsi Gabbard, Trump’s controversial nominee for director of national intelligence, clears Senate committee vote
item.description: After Gabbard’s narrow approval by the Senate Intelligence Committee, she will face a full Senate vote next week. Gabbard, a former Democratic congresswoman from Hawaii, faced bipartisan skepticism about her suitability for overseeing the full roster of U.S. intelligence agencies during a tense confirmation hearing last week.

item.title: Families and LGBTQ advocacy groups sue to halt Trump order aiming to restrict care for transgender youth
item.description: The lawsuit comes as hospitals across the country have paused some gender transition care for people younger than 19 in response to President Donald Trump's executive order seeking to block federal support for such treatment.

item.title: D.C. Council expels Trayon White Sr. (D-Ward 8) over ethics rules, the first time the body has taken such a step in its history
item.description: The punishment results from a federal charge that White took $35,000 in bribes from an associate seeking to extend government contracts. White has pleaded not guilty to the charge. He is still eligible to run for his seat again in a special election.

item.title: FBI agents sue to keep officials from compiling a list that could be used to fire thousands involved in Trump and Jan. 6 cases
item.description: Attorneys for the agents, who filed suit anonymously in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, said any effort to use that information as a basis to fire FBI employees would be unlawful, retaliatory and a violation of civil service protections.

item.title: Layoffs across the federal government are ‘likely’ if not enough workers take the deferred resignation offer, internal email warns
item.description: The assistant commissioner of a division of the General Services Administration told staff to prepare for deep cuts. Federal workers have until Thursday to accept an offer to resign now and be paid through September.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Mom won’t stop rehashing every painful detail of Dad’s final days
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Mom won’t stop rehashing every painful detail of Dad’s final days

item.title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Trump’s nominee to serve as the top U.S. health official, clears key hurdle for Senate confirmation
item.description: Kennedy, who faced tough questioning in recent hearings over his positions on vaccines, abortion and other major health-care issues, was advanced by the Senate Finance Committee. He still needs approval by the full Senate to be confirmed as secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services.

item.title: Trump’s tariffs. Power grab. Immigration crackdown. Netanyahu visit. Fire insurance. Microplastics. Cannabis drinks. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: China institutes a 15% levy on U.S. coal and gas in retaliation after Trump’s tariffs take effect
item.description: Beijing also imposed additional tariffs on farm machinery and other products from the United States.

item.title: A fed-up sheriff jailed children who made school shooting threats: ‘I’m going to perp walk your kid’
item.description: Thousands of students made threats after the deadly Apalachee High School shooting in Georgia, a Washington Post analysis finds — leading frustrated police to arrest nearly 500. Nowhere was the crackdown more harsh than in one Florida county.

item.title: Trump preps order to dismantle Education Department as DOGE works to raze it from within, officials say
item.description: Closing the agency would require congressional approval, so the new administration hopes to diminish it. Already, the White House has tried to reduce the agency’s workforce by putting scores of employees on administrative leave, pressuring staff to voluntarily quit and sending DOGE officials in to probe books, people familiar with the matter say.

item.title: Trudeau, after call with Trump, says U.S. will pause tariffs on Canada for 30 days
item.description: In a tweet, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he had a good call with President Donald Trump, will appoint a fentanyl czar and will implement the $900 million border plan his government announced in December.

item.title: Analysis: The 2025 Grammys performances, ranked from best to worst
item.description: On Beyoncé and Kendrick’s big night, a new generation of pop stars wowed onstage. Here’s what impressed us — and what was forgettable.

item.title: I haven’t filed tax returns in 5 years. Can I correct this without going to jail? Our personal finance columnist takes your questions.
item.description: I haven’t filed tax returns in 5 years. Can I correct this without going to jail? Our personal finance columnist takes your questions.

item.title: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau halts all work after Trump appoints Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent as its acting director
item.description: The CFPB is actively engaged in litigation with banks, tech firms and others it oversees. Elon Musk has previously called to “delete” the agency, and President Donald Trump fired its director over the weekend.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Closeness of friendship with ex-wife makes girlfriend uncomfortable
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Closeness of friendship with ex-wife makes girlfriend uncomfortable

item.title: Scientists discover microplastics are building up in our brains — with potentially dangerous effects for human health
item.description: New research published Monday in Nature Medicine shows that microplastics are breaking the blood-brain barrier — and building up in the human body. Brains from people who died in 2024 had 50 percent more plastic fragments in them than samples from 2016, indicating that the particles are accumulating as plastics production has boomed worldwide. The scientists also found that the brains of patients with dementia had significantly more microplastics than healthy ones.

item.title: Should you take the Trump administration’s buyout offer? A risk expert explains how to make a good decision.
item.description: A handful of prompts can help you decide how to decide.

item.title: Trump will delay tariffs against Mexico for one month, Mexican president says
item.description: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum tweeted that she had a “good conversation” with President Donald Trump and pledged to deploy 10,000 members of the Mexican national guard to the border to combat drug trafficking, particularly of fentanyl. The tariffs had been set to take effect early Tuesday.

item.title: A new chatbot in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Dow slumps 500 points as Trump tariffs, fears of trade war rattle global markets
item.description: The S&P 500 and tech-heavy Nasdaq also fell sharply Monday after the Trump administration imposed sweeping levies on goods from Canada, Mexico and China, which all promised retaliatory measures.

item.title: Trump’s tariffs. Elon Musk. Plane wreckage. Hostage release. School threats. Grammy winners. Near-Earth asteroid. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Secretary of State Marco Rubio backtracks on Trump’s near-total foreign aid freeze, issues waiver for ‘life-saving’ assistance
item.description: The State Department on Friday issued a blanket "stop-work" order, immediately pausing almost all U.S. foreign assistance. On Tuesday, amid global confusion and concern, the State Dept. abruptly and quietly sent a notice that seemed to indicate broad swaths of this funding could continue. Humanitarian groups around the world are still unsure what it means for them.
